snippet: The Academy is considering a rule change that would allow only documentaries that have been reviewed in The New York Times or The Los Angeles Times be eligible for an Oscar.
abstract: The Academy is considering a rule change that would allow only documentaries that have been reviewed in The New York Times or The Los Angeles Times be eligible for an Oscar.
lead_paragraph: The ballots for this year's Oscars were only recently sent out and already there's a move afoot to change the rules for next year's ceremony. The Academy may move this week to consider only documentaries reviewed by The New York Times or The Los Angeles Times eligible for an Oscar, our colleague Michael Cieply reports. The change would probably trim the number of features under consideration, which rose more than 20 percent from 2010 to 2011, but he adds it would also affect DocuWeeks, screenings sponsored by the International Documentary Association: "The new rule puts a squeeze on those who do not have a commercial distributor, and particularly calls into question the viability of DocuWeeks, which has consistently shoehorned films into the Oscar process." What do our critics think of the plan to qualify only films that have been reviewed in the paper? "It's flattering," A.O. Scott says. Read more »
